awd_titl_txt: I/UCRC:  Water and Environmental Technology Center
awd_abstract_narration:
In Phase II operation, the Water and Environmental Technology (WET) I/UCRC intends to minimize any adverse effects of emerging contaminants (EC) on human health and/or the environment. The research challenges in this area include the need for more scientific information about levels, fate, transport, ecological and health impacts of ECs in the environment, the need for improved detection and monitoring capabilities, and for new cost-effective treatment technologies and optimization of existing operations at both water and wastewater treatment plants.  Center engineers and environmental scientists utilizing microbial, chemical, and mathematic approaches will work collaboratively in coordination with center industry representatives to perform this research.  WET's industrial, need-focused research program aims to enhance scientific understanding and help address potentially significant health and environmental problems.

The challenges addressed and potential benefits derived from the work of the Water and Environmental Technology (WET) I/UCRC impact several industries including: the Pharmaceutical and Personal Care Products Industries; the Oil and Natural Gas Industry; Pesticide and other Chemicals Industry; entities that treat wastewater and drinking water; and companies that create and service technologies for the removal of contaminants from water.  Students and faculty will experience state of the art research projects of value to both industry and the community. Many member companies have overseas installations, and students will be exposed to regulatory, technological, social and cultural aspects of different countries, enhancing their global experiences. In addition, every effort will be made to engage and involve minority students, as well as students and teachers from local K-12 schools, in part through existing programs at the center's institutions.  The Center will further enhance the ongoing efforts at the three institutions of integrating research into classroom teaching.

NSF OUTCOMES REPORT:   NSF WATER AND ENVIRONMENTAL TECHNOLOGY CENTER (WET), THE UNIVERSITY OF ARIZONA

1,     Enhanced Water Resources

The treatment of reclaimed water for subsequent potable reuse is of paramount importance to communities in arid regions where rainfall is scant. The WET Center evaluated multiple new technologies for advanced treatment of reclaimed water, potentially enabling direct or indirect potable reuse, if needed, when water shortages becomes apparent in a community (see Figure 1 for advanced water treatment train). In desert areas, this is critically important since reclaimed water is the only renewable water resource available.

 2.     Improved Water Quality

Potable water quality is becoming increasingly important nationally, as evidenced by the recent tragic events in Flint Michigan. To assure communities of appropriate potable water quality, the WET Center developed new technologies to detect potential water quality contaminants. For example, a real-time sensor for human pathogenic viruses was developed for norovirus, a major source of water and foodborne disease. This technology involved an immunoassay coupled to smartphone technology, allowing for the instantaneous detection of viruses in water. Another example is the use of electromagnetic technology to enhance disinfection of microbial contaminants via chlorine, with reduced disinfection bi-products.

 3.     Protection of Public Health

A critically important outcome of the WET Center was the contribution to the newly emerging discipline: Wastewater-Based Epidemiology (WBE). This involved the monitoring of wastewater for SARS-CoV-2, the infections virus responsible for the devastating COVID-19 pandemic of 2020. Specifically, WBE was used to monitor the wastewater from student dormitories at the University of Arizona. Wastewater positive for SARS-CoV-2 was targeted for clinical testing of dorm students. This strategy of WBE coupled to targeted clinical testing reduced exponential spread of the virus by identifying not only symptomatic infections but also asymptomatic infections. The two major outcomes of this were: i) reduced disease, potentially saving lives; and ii) the development of a strategy that allowed the University of Arizona to remain open throughout the Fall Semester of 2020, whereas many universities nationally were forced to close because of COVID-19. These activities resulted in a media frenzy (see Figure 2 for newspaper headings).

 An additional example of public health protection was the WET Center study on perfluorinated compounds (PFCs or PFAS) originating from land application of biosolids. This study originated from enhanced concern over potential groundwater contamination with compounds such as PFAS or PFOA that can be detected in biosolids. The study utilized analysis of soils from long-term land application sites with known loading rates of biosolids applied since 1985. The study demonstrated that accumulated PFAS compounds in the land-applied soils were at very low concentrations. Additionally, over 90% of the PFAS compounds were attenuated in the surface foot of soil, illustrating that the potential for contamination of groundwater was minimal.

 4.     Education Outcomes

During the tenure of the WET Center from 2014-2020, 12 graduate students were trained and 10 undergraduates. Of the graduate students, six received Ph.D. degrees and six graduated with Masters degrees. In addition, several post-doctoral students were trained including both national and international students.

 5.     Extension Outcomes

The Center was very active in disseminating new information on science and technology at the local, state, national and international level. WET Center faculty presented data from funded projects at numerous conferences, and also published over 30 peer-review publications. In addition to this UA faculty attended bi-annual conferences (12 in all) with other WET Center Sites (Temple University and Arizona State University).
